qas.question: How is the complex impedance with dielectric represented mathematically?
How is the complex capacitance without dielectric represented mathematically?
Why is the value of C0 unattainable in reality?

answers.text: even the quantum vacuum is predicted to exhibit nonideal behavior

qas.question: Under what condition is the approximation C0 sufficiently accurate for calculation purposes?
How is the complex capacitance mathematically represented with the dielectric present?
How is the non-complex impedance with dielectric represented mathematically?
How is the complex capacitance with dielectric represented mathematically?

plausible_answers.text: even the quantum vacuum is predicted to exhibit nonideal behavior

qas.question: Why isn't the value of C0 unattainable in reality?
Under what condition is the approximation C0 sufficiently inaccurate for calculation purposes?
How is the complex capacitance mathematically unrepresented with the dielectric present?

context: where a single prime denotes the real part and a double prime the imaginary part, <a0_0><b5_0>Z(ω)<b5_0/><a0_0/> is the complex impedance with the dielectric present, <a4_0><b9_0>Ccmplx(ω)<b9_0/><a4_0/> is the so-called complex capacitance with the dielectric present, and <a1_0><b6_0>C0<b6_0/><a1_0/> is the capacitance without the dielectric. (Measurement "without the dielectric" in principle means measurement in free space, an unattainable goal inasmuch as <a2_0><b7_0>even the quantum vacuum is predicted to exhibit nonideal behavior<b7_0/><a2_0/>, such as dichroism. For practical purposes, when measurement errors are taken into account, often a measurement <a3_0>in <b8_0>terrestrial vacuum<b8_0/><a3_0/>, or simply a calculation of C0, is sufficiently accurate.)
